content: How can I help you today?

I don’t really know where to start. Things at home have been a mess. My wife and I are constantly arguing because we can't figure out how to help our son, and it feels like my marriage is falling apart. I don’t even know if talking about this will help.

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like there's been a lot of stress at home, and you're feeling overwhelmed by the tension in your family right now. Relationships can feel especially hard when you're trying to navigate helping someone you care deeply about, like your son. How are you managing with all of this going on?

Honestly, I’m not managing well at all. I can’t focus at work, I don’t feel like doing anything I used to enjoy, and it’s like every little thing just piles onto how bad I already feel. I’m just constantly on edge or shutting down completely.

You’re carrying a heavy load, and it’s really affecting different parts of your life—your work, the things you used to enjoy, and even how you feel emotionally. It’s exhausting feeling on edge all the time or like you just shut down. It sounds like you're wanting something to change but aren’t sure where to begin. What's most important to you right now as you think about everything you're going through?

I just want to figure out how to help my son and at least feel like I’m doing something right. And I want to be there for my wife and daughter too, but it feels impossible when I’m this drained. I don’t even know if I’m capable of fixing anything, but keeping my family together is what matters most to me.

Your dedication to your family is really clear—you’re trying to be there for your son, your wife, and your daughter, all while dealing with the weight of feeling drained yourself. You’re holding on to what matters most to you, even in a tough situation where solutions feel out of reach. It takes a lot of care and strength to keep pushing forward like you are. What could help you feel even a little more supported as you work on keeping your family together?

Honestly, I don’t even know. I feel like I’m just stuck in this cycle where nothing helps, no matter what I try. Maybe figuring out how to help my son would be a start, but I wouldn’t even know where to begin with that. It’s just all too much.

It makes sense that feeling stuck like this adds to the weight you’re carrying—it’s hard when no matter what you try, it seems like nothing helps. Even with everything feeling overwhelming, your focus on finding ways to help your son shows how much you care and are willing to try. Would it feel helpful to talk more about what’s been going on with him? Or is there another direction you’d rather explore right now?

It’s all just been so overwhelming, and I’m not sure where to even start talking about it. My son has been acting out a lot—just constant outbursts, trouble at school, and it feels like nothing we try makes a difference. It’s frustrating and heartbreaking, and it has my wife and me arguing all the time about what to do next. Maybe talking about him more could help.

It sounds like what’s happening with your son is deeply affecting everyone—it’s heartbreaking to see him struggling, frustrating when nothing seems to improve, and stressful when it creates tension between you and your wife too. You’re carrying a lot of care and responsibility as you try to navigate this, and it’s understandable that it feels overwhelming. Would you like to share more about what’s been going on with him or about the ways you’ve tried to support him so far?

It’s been hard to get through to him. He gets angry or shuts down when we try to talk, and at school, he’s been acting out and getting into trouble. We’ve tried talking calmly, setting boundaries, and even getting stricter, but nothing seems to get through. It’s frustrating because I just want to help him, and I’m not sure what else to do.

It sounds like you’ve been trying so many different approaches to help him—calm conversations, setting boundaries, even being stricter—but none of them are breaking through, and that leaves you feeling frustrated and unsure of what more you can do. Your desire to help your son is clear, even in these tough moments where he seems unreachable. What do you think might be going on underneath his anger or shutting down?

Maybe he’s feeling overwhelmed or struggling with something he doesn’t know how to express. I honestly don’t know for sure, and it’s hard to guess when he won’t open up. I just know he’s hurting, and I feel like I’m failing him by not figuring out how to help.

It sounds like you’re sensing that your son may be dealing with something deeper, even if he hasn’t been able to share it with you yet. Seeing him hurting and feeling like you’re struggling to help must be incredibly hard—it’s coming from how much you care about him and want to ease his pain. Despite how tough this has been, it sounds like you’re still willing to keep trying. What do you think might help create some space for him to open up, even if it’s just a small step?

It’s hard to say what might work because nothing’s worked so far. Maybe he feels like we’re not really understanding him or listening the way he needs us to. I don’t even know how to create that space for him, though—it feels like we’re just stuck.

It sounds like you’re open to the possibility that your son might be needing a different kind of understanding or connection, but figuring out how to create that kind of space feels challenging when things have already been so overwhelming. You’re doing the best you can to connect with him, even in this difficult situation, and your willingness to explore what might work says a lot about your care for him. Have there been moments, even small ones, where he seemed to respond more positively or let his guard down a bit?

It’s hard to say—a lot of the time, he keeps those walls up. But there have been rare moments, like when we’re playing a game he likes or just sitting quietly together, where he seems a little calmer or more open. Those moments don’t last long, though, and I never know how to carry them forward into something more.

Those rare moments of calm or connection—like playing a game he enjoys or sitting quietly together—sound really meaningful, even if they’re brief. They might be glimpses of what helps him feel safe or understood in the moment, even if it’s hard to sustain them. It’s frustrating when those moments feel fleeting, especially when you want them to lead to something deeper. What do you think could help you build on those moments, or at least try to expand them in ways that feel natural to him?

Maybe if I focus on those small moments and let him take the lead, it could help. Like, I could try to be more patient and not push too much when he’s calm, just let him know I’m there for him. It’s hard, though, not knowing if it’ll actually make a difference.

Focusing on those small moments and letting him take the lead sounds like a thoughtful approach—it could help create a space where he feels less pressure and more supported in a way that works for him. It’s natural to feel unsure about whether it will make a difference, especially when things have been so challenging, but your patience and willingness to try could mean a lot to him over time. How do you think you could get started with this idea?
